Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: The shrill site alarm jolts me from my focus, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. Protocol is drilled into us: when that alarm sounds, you don’t hesitate, you don’t question, you just move. I join the stream of hard hats heading for the muster point, but my mind is racing. Today is voting day, and I’d planned to head straight to the polling station after my shift. I reach for my wallet, only to realize my ID isn’t there—I left it in my locker, back inside the building we’re evacuating. The foreman’s voice echoes in my head: “No one goes back for any reason.” But if I don’t have my ID, I can’t vote. I know I could fetch it later, but what if the site stays closed for hours? My team expects me to follow safety rules, but my civic duty tugs at me just as hard. I stand at the muster point, torn between being a responsible worker and a responsible citizen, anxiety twisting in my gut as I weigh the demands of both worlds.
